Description: Small mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; back skewed, with basic divisions indicated in single line for clypeus, prothorax and elytra; at side, thick legs simply modelled, with undercut triangle; underside incised with quadruped walking to right (lion, goat ?); longitudinally pierced; in very bright light blue paste; all surfaces rubbed and details indistinct.
Curator's comments: The scarab belongs to a type produced at the Scarab Factory (on this production, see Webb forthcoming) and widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, especially in Carthage, Kerkouan, Sicily and Gibraltar, but also in Greece, Cyprus and Rhodes (Gorton 1996, 118-121, type XXXIII, subtype A25-41, see especially A38 for this piece). Rather than a quadruped , Gorton identified the figure represented on the underside as a sphinx (Gorton 1996, 118). The surface being badly abraded especially in the area of the figure, it is difficult to confirm such identification. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 129)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 119, Type XXXIII A38)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.25) (phase 3)
